Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: The Psychology of Fear: Cultural Orientation and Response to Ebola Threat

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Ebola is one of the deadliest contagious diseases to emerge into the public consciousness in recent years. Accompanied by truly gruesome and deadly images, it has been a source of much fear, xenophobia, and social division across the world. While it makes obvious sense to increase some vigilance and engage in self-protective health behaviors, most health experts maintain that the actual risk of contracting Ebola is extremely low, at least outside of the directly affected regions in West Africa. Yet, the degree to which people respond to the potential risk is vastly disproportionate to the actual risk. Thus, in many parts of the world, the actual costs of Ebola are not the disease itself, but the negative psychological and behavioral effects - both individual and social - that are motivated by fear. Fear and social division are not only consequences of Ebola, but they have the potential to transform and perpetuate negative social consequences. Although the US is currently at low risk for Ebola contagion, the potential costs of individual distress as well as restrictive group protection behaviors are real. The present research proposes a theoretically-based intervention to attenuate these negative effects. Moreover, beyond the current Ebola concern, the knowledge gained from this research will be relevant to other, continually occurring, international threats of contagious diseases by potentially mitigating their psychological and social costs. This project was submitted in response to NSF 15-006 Dear Colleague Letter on the Ebola Virus.

This research aims to understand the psychological mechanism of fear-driven individual and social consequences. Drawing from the knowledge-base of social, cultural, and health psychology, two studies using large nationally representative samples will focus on two distinct responses to disease-related fear: 1) anxiety and stress that are detrimental to individual well-being; and 2) manifestations of group-protection to minimize risk. The project will investigate whether cultural orientation (individualism vs. collectivism within the US) will influence which psychological response set is most likely. The prediction is that individualists will be more concerned with self-protection, and thus, are more likely to experience disproportionate anxiety and stress, whereas collectivists will be more concerned with group protection. Based on this model, the proposed research will also test the effectiveness of psychological interventions (self- and group-affirmation) to address the threat and reduce the psychological and social costs of the specter of Ebola.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The present research investigated how people respond to the threat of global pandemic, and how the cultural value of collectivism influences this response, focusing on responses to Ebola scare in 2014. As reported in the media, in response to gruesome images of Ebola many people evinced strong fear and xenophobic tendencies, such as supporting travel bans to limit contact with out-group members. Although such fear and xenophobia is a common response among most people, the degree to which individuals display such tendencies varies. This research proposed a novel theoretical model to understand the role of cultural values in how people respond to disease threats, integrating theories from social, cultural, and health psychology. More specifically, a study, using a nationally representative sample of Americans, investigated this question, and found that people with collectivistic values (either as a personally held value or as a function of living in a US state that is collectivistic) tend to react less strongly when they feel that they are vulnerable to the disease. In addition, it appears that these responses occur because more collectivistic people are more likely to believe that their group is capable of protecting them, and thus, they are less likely to feel the need to respond to the scare with xenophobia.

Although there are many distinctive features that make the case of Ebola unique, the knowledge gained from the current research may be generalized to other cases involving high-profile diseases that share some key characteristics. For example, within the past decade many parts of the world showed similar panic responses over Swine Flu, the West Nile virus outbreak, SARS, and Zika. Thus the findings are likely impact a wide range of disciplines such as public health and political science. Furthermore, by understanding how cultural factors systematically and predictably set the course for downstream consequences of perceiving threat of infectious disease such as Ebola, the research can impact global studies and anthropology. Follow up studies have broadened the theory to understand the processes of responding to non-disease related societal threats and issues such as terrorism and climate change.

The impact of this research may be seen in the interest in organizations such as Direct Relief and the public health team of Sierre Leone health officials. By understanding individuals' fear responses to pandemic and how it translates into policy preferences and attitudes towards people from disease-afflicted regions, this research provides new insight into problems of xenophobia and prejudice. The theoretical understanding of how the fear of disease translates into self- and group-protective actions and the psychological mechanisms underpinning fear responses has impact for how people confront other large societal issues and threats.
